commander.name: Bernard Cyril Freyberg
commander.previous_service: British Army (World War I), New Zealand Staff Corps
commander.notes: General Officer Commanding 2nd New Zealand Expeditionary Force

chief_of_staff.name: Unknown
chief_of_staff.notes: Chief of Staff position existed but name not confirmed for Q1 1941

staff_strength.notes: Divisional headquarters and signals estimated strength

operational_status.notes: 5th Brigade arriving Egypt January-March 1941, full division not yet assembled or combat ready in Q1. Some units still in transit. Division deployed to Greece in March 1941.
operational_status.deployment_timeline: 4th and 6th Brigades in Egypt since late 1940, 5th Brigade completing arrival Q1 1941

light_tanks.notes: Divisional Cavalry Regiment received Light Tanks Mk VI in October 1941 (not yet available in Q1)

halftracks.notes: British Commonwealth divisions did not use halftracks in 1941

armored_cars.notes: Armored cars not standard divisional equipment in Q1 1941

Universal Carrier (Bren Gun Carrier).distribution: Infantry battalions (approx 13-14 per battalion across 9 battalions), Divisional Cavalry Regiment (6 carriers initially)

carriers.notes: Divisional Cavalry received 14 additional Bren carriers in August 1941 (not yet in Q1)

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.organization: 3 Field Regiments (4th, 5th, 6th) with 24 guns each (3 batteries of 8 guns per regiment in Q1 1941)
Ordnance QF 25-pounder.notes: Standard Commonwealth divisional field artillery. Each infantry brigade supported by one field regiment.

Ordnance QF 2-pounder.organization: 7th Anti-Tank Regiment, plus organic battalion anti-tank platoons

Bofors 40mm L/60.organization: 14th Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment (3 batteries: 41st, 42nd, 43rd LAA Batteries)

anti_aircraft.notes: Some units may have had additional Vickers .303 AA mounts, not counted separately

reconnaissance.notes: Air support provided by RAF units, not organic to division

supply_status.notes: Supply situation in Q1 1941 while assembling in Egypt was adequate. Division not yet in sustained combat operations.

subordinate_units.notes: Regional recruitment: Auckland, Wellington, Canterbury-Otago districts
Arriving Egypt January-March 1941. Includes 28th Maori Battalion (attached). Brigadier Hargest commanded 5th Brigade.

subordinate_units.composition: 24th Battalion (Northern Military District), 25th Battalion (Central Military District), 26th Battalion (Southern Military District)
subordinate_units.notes: In Egypt since late 1940. Brigadier Barrowclough commanded 6th Brigade.

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 4th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery
subordinate_units.equipment: 24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns (3 batteries of 8 guns)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 5th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery
subordinate_units.equipment: 24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns (3 batteries of 8 guns)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 6th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery
subordinate_units.equipment: 24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns (3 batteries of 8 guns)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 7th Anti-Tank Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery
14th Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery
subordinate_units.equipment: 24x Bofors 40mm L/60 light anti-aircraft guns (3 batteries: 41st, 42nd, 43rd LAA Batteries)
6x Universal Carriers (Bren Gun Carriers), various motorcycles and light vehicles
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional reconnaissance unit. Received 14 additional carriers in August 1941 and Light Tanks Mk VI in October 1941 (not yet in Q1).
RASC equivalent - New Zealand Army Service Corps
Multiple field ambulance units, divisional medical services

special_capabilities: Mountain and rough terrain operations (New Zealand soldiers skilled in outdoor operations)
Strong esprit de corps and national identity
tactical_innovations: New Zealand troops demonstrated initiative and adaptability
Strong small-unit leadership at NCO level
known_issues: Still assembling in Q1 1941 - not fully combat ready
5th Brigade only completing arrival in March 1941
Limited anti-tank capability (2-pounder inadequate against later German tanks)
No organic armor (tanks) in divisional structure
Training ongoing for desert/Mediterranean theater conditions
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Training for desert warfare ongoing in Egypt Q1 1941. Division would deploy to Greece in March 1941 before gaining extensive desert experience.

special_rules: Commonwealth Division: Standard British doctrine and equipment
High Morale: New Zealand national pride and volunteer force
Forming Status: In Q1 1941, division still assembling and training
Elite Small Unit Leadership: +1 to NCO initiative rolls
wargaming_data.notes: In Q1 1941, division was not yet in combat. First major action was Greece in March 1941.

source: British Army List April 1941 (Official - Primary Source) - Commander confirmed
New Zealand Electronic Text Centre (NZETC) - Official NZ military history archives
Order of Battle website (balagan.info) - Brigade and battalion structure
Web search results - Artillery regiments, Divisional Cavalry, equipment details
Standard Commonwealth division tables of organization 1940-1941
TM30-410 British Army Handbook 1942 (US Army intelligence)

confidence_breakdown.notes: Commander and organizational structure highly confident from primary sources. Equipment counts are estimates based on standard Commonwealth TO&E and partial historical records. Specific subordinate unit commander names not found for Q1 1941 (except brigade commanders). Personnel strength is typical Commonwealth division estimate.

known_gaps: Specific commander names for most subordinate units (regiments, battalions, companies)
Precise equipment counts (estimates based on standard TO&E)
Exact operational readiness percentages for equipment
Detailed personnel breakdown by subordinate unit
Specific locations of units within Egypt in Q1 1941
Chief of Staff name and other senior staff officers
Precise arrival dates for 5th Brigade units in Q1 1941
Some artillery battery commanders and designations
validation.methodology: Data compiled from British Army List April 1941 (primary source for commander), New Zealand official military history sources, order of battle references, and standard Commonwealth division organization tables. Equipment counts estimated from typical Commonwealth division TO&E 1940-1941. Personnel strength based on standard division establishment (approx 16,000-17,000 for Commonwealth infantry division).

notes: This is a NEW ZEALAND division - classified as nation='british' per user instructions (Commonwealth forces included in British classification)
In Q1 1941 (January-March), the 2nd New Zealand Division was assembling in Egypt
4th and 6th Brigades had arrived in Egypt in late 1940
5th Brigade was arriving throughout Q1 1941, with last units completing arrival in March
Division was not fully combat ready in Q1 1941 - still in training and assembly phase
Division deployed to Greece in March 1941 (end of Q1) as part of 'W Force'
The 28th (Maori) Battalion was a unique unit, generally attached to 5th Brigade but sometimes rotated between brigades
Equipment counts are estimates based on standard Commonwealth division TO&E for 1941
Artillery organization: Each field regiment had 3 batteries of 8 guns (24 guns per regiment) in early 1941. Later reorganized to 2 batteries of 12 guns in late 1941.
Divisional Cavalry Regiment initially had only 6 Bren carriers in Q1 1941. Received 14 more in August 1941 and light tanks in October 1941.
No organic tank units in division. New Zealand division followed standard Commonwealth infantry division structure.
All New Zealand battalions recruited from specific geographic regions (Northern/Auckland, Central/Wellington, Southern/Canterbury-Otago)
General Freyberg was a highly decorated WWI veteran (Victoria Cross recipient) and commanded the division throughout most of WWII
Division served with distinction in Greece, Crete, North Africa, and Italy
In Q1 1941, division was under command of XIII Corps, Western Desert Force (later renamed Eighth Army)
